commentBody: That took me half the time yesterday did.
Very nice puzzle Ms. Miller! Yeah it was crunchy indeed. We like crunchy though, keep 'em coming pls.
19A [narrow passage: abbr] is STR..... is that an abbreviation for stairway? What's an STR? I'm not sure I know that one.

I had my fears halfway through the across clues and not much entered but then things started to click.  Sometimes I doubt that an 'obvious' answer could be correct and hesitate to enter. 

Fun puzzle, thanks!

I enjoyed this one.  It had lots of twisty clues and plenty of fresh fill.  It took me awhile to get going, but I picked up speed as I went along.  The app generously added 17 minutes to my solve time, at least that’s better than the 3 hours it added a couple of weeks ago.  The timing has become so erratic that I can’t use the stats to judge how I’m doing against my norms.  I don’t solve for speed anyway, but I did like having a gauge as to how I finished a puzzle vis a vis my usual performance.  Oh well.

I don’t often quibble with clues, but, as a birder, I’m not familiar with any buff colored EGRETs.  The snowy, great and cattle EGRETs are pretty bright white, and the reddish egret is not buff either.  Anyway, if there is a buff EGRET outside the US, I haven’t seen one, and I’ll stand corrected.

I was delighted to see Kenneth GRAHAME pop up in the puzzle, and he would have been one of my early footholds, if, that is, I’d remembered how to spell his name.  I was only confident enough to enter the GRA until I had some crosses.  The Wind In The Willows was one of my favorite childhood books.  Mole rediscovering his old home always brings a tear of nostalgia to my eye and the Piper At The Gates Of Dawn chapter is one of the most lyrical episodes in all of children’s literature, and one of the best descriptions of a mystical experience in any literature.  I look forward to reading it again with my grandson, and it may break my heart if he doesn’t share my enthusiasm.

Pretty manageable except for the NW. Got stuck on several wrong answers that I was trying to make work: breAD for SALAD, staRRATING for UBERRATING, and iceMONSTER for SEAMONSTER. Anyway, eventually made it out the other side with the gold star (#699 in the streak!).
What was Ms. Miller's byline that made you smile, Deb?  I looked around but couldn't find it.  Thanks!

It's been more than 25 years since the US minted quarters with an eagle on the reverse. Since 1999, it's been states, territories, national parks, American women and more. Of course, there are still a kajillion eagle-backed quarters from 1998 and earlier.
great puzzle, was tricky to solve but rewarding when i finally did.
Solved it in half the time of yesterdays, first for me. Great puzzle.

A rather negative puzzle for such a positive experience...I'm talking the three long entries naysayingly phrased: NO GREAT SHAKES, IT'S NOT A RACE, NOT A LITTLE...with the related GOOD ENOUGH and the PITS, it would appear that the little dude inside this grid is not expecting anyone to leave a positive UBER RATING or yell ENCORE!  Well, little dude, before you take your sob story to the tiki bar, I'm here to tell you that you did good. Better than good. And not just by a little. Encore!

I admit putting down GRAND CHORD for a bit -- seemed like it could be a thing related to a minor chord -- and briefly entertained the notion that Bjorn Borg supports women in technology, which he very well might, but not as much as Anita does. Not as much...see? That negative talk, it's contagious!
According to a New York Times article Buford, WY was not sold on eBay but by Williams & Williams at the Buford Trading Post.
Not especially tough, but any puzzle with OTIS Redding in it is plenty GOOD ENOUGH.

An uplifting puzzle after a fraught Friday, despite the Debbie Downer SLANT.  It may have been NOGREATSHAKES, but it was GOODENOUGH to slow me down, and no rEGRETS about the time spent solving It.

Let's be honest here, it was a fun puzzle, and I'm looking forward to an ENCORE, Ms. Miller.  Thank you!
Great solo puzzle, Willa!  Clever and fun to solve. Looking forward to the next one. And yay for women in technology!

I thought today was a Thursday so I keep looking for the revealer. 

I can’t say I was a big fan of this. It seemed way too heavy on proper nouns. Especially the very middle. 
That said. It was fair though. Had some good clues that could be interpreted different ways, so answer not so obvious. At least not for me. 

I got the gold on a Friday. So I guess I’m happy I got through it. But like i said. Maybe I was salty because I didn’t know any of the proper noun entries.
Ms. Miller, I enjoyed your fun puzzle and it made me happy!   Thank you!
Eliminate the answer STR and you have a perfect puzzle, but I the constructor was infatuated with the LEAR answer. A pleasure to solve.
A fun one and I think a Friday PB for me at 25:19 - only made possible by crosses and process on elimination in several spots.
Fun puzzle!
Congratulations on your solo debut, Willa. I feel like I was definitely on the same wavelength. It wasn’t quite a PB for a Friday, but pretty close. I liked it NOT just A LITTLE, but rather a lot!!

A fun way to spend 13 minutes on a Thursday night, a minute faster than yesterday’s effort.  No where near a personal best though…

I didn’t know the Pixar film nor the name that intersected it.  Does that constitute a Natick?
Okay, finished this at 1 pm.  Great fun!  Now back to the piano.  Awaiting the Saturday drop.
The town of Buford was NOT sold on eBay. That’s a completely false “fun fact” made up for a blog years ago. It was sold by Williams & Williams at auction.

My knowledge of sweet beverages is a bit shakey.

(But it used to be the dairy best.)

Splendid puzzle. Only one question for the constructor/editor … did they have to look up how to spell jörmungandr 😀

No lookups unless in desperation self imposed rule made top left corner take a bit longer than the rest. 

Thanks for nice Friday morning start of the day

Screen turned gold and I let out a silent YES! so as not to wake the sleeper beside me. Felt like a solid accomplishment to end the day. 

Great puzzle!

Interesting, Deb's takes on tricky clues.

For me, any clue including a question mark (e.g., 27D and 42D, which Deb included as tricky) is decidedly *not* tricky; the ? makes me look for word play/trickery.

Today, the clues which gave me the most trouble were 1A (could not stop thinking of uni classes (yes, I know SALAD has been clued identically or similarly many times in the past)), and 4D, using "Ready" (to fight) as a verb.
Completely enjoyed this. Not too difficult, mostly seemed I was on the same page as Willa, yet a few things required additional thought. Nice one!

Frunchy!

That NE block was a bear, though, and not the cute, cuddly kind. My first fill was “Dow” for the exchange letters, and while I figured the WIT founder would be a woman, I knew no other Borg than “Bjorn”. Also, sue me but I’ve never seen Succession. But a couple of lookups later (ah, ANITA! Now I know two Borgs!) and I was on the right path.

The rest of it fell together pretty quickly. Just enough short words to tie things together, and the clever clueing did not disappoint. Despite my few hiccups, I think I enjoyed this more than the usual Friday.

I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle, and thought the clues “Features of some monks and punks” for SHAVED HEADS and “Unfortunate twists” for SPRAINS were especially clever. 

I propose a new meaning for IPO ….  Inspired Puzzle Offering. 

Congratulations, Willa, on your solo debut.
I'll like to thank the Miller for the BRAN. Diverting solve. Utterly enjoyable.

thanks for the awesome puzzle! I didn't know about 1/3 of the trivia and clues, but could SUSS them out from the crosses, it was a fun and enjoyable half hour for me! By the way, I was wondering how to use NOT A LITTLE in a sentence to mean "very". I only know how to use "not a little bit" as in "not a little bit sorry" to mean not sorry at all, which is the opposite of "very sorry".

This was a fun puzzle.  For me, a little heavy on proper names, I didn't know any of them.  One other nit is 13a.  The clue, imho, should read, What you might give, after being taken for a ride, not what you might get.

Thaks for a fun puzzle Willa!

I enjoyed this, but it shows me how differently from each other people think.  I got the tricky clues first.  I got the SHAVED HEADS with no crosses at all.  But for some reason a CALL option took me forever.  And a HINT=NOTE?  Hm.  

Like many others, I had Bjorn first but realized that was probably not correct.  And SEVENOFNINE didn't fit.

Typical tough Friday for me, and had to cheat a bit to get going in a couple of places, but ended up being an enjoyable workout as things finally dawned on me. Nice puzzle. Answer history searches today: Somehow 29a (EGRET) led me to realize that one old favorite song is 15 letters: MISSOTISREGRETS And that's been an answer in 4 puzzles. And... don't even remember exactly how this one popped into my head, but also realized that WALTZINGMATILDA is also 15 letters. And that led to a quite remarkable puzzle. A Thursday from March 18, 1999 by Rand H. Burns. In that puzzle that answer was... sort of the reveal - clued as "National song, theme of today's puzzle." And some other answers: SWAGMAN JUMBUCK TUCKERBAG BILLABONG Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/18/1999&g=37&d=A Might put another puzzle find in a reply later on. Maybe. I'm done. ...

Strands Thread.  Please save all spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #320
“The time of our lives”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

Very nice. Only issues for me - ETS, despite flying saucer explanation, I don’t get it. Same with ONE. Is that just a guess?
And SALAD. Surprised at that one. Is that really a first course in US?

A testament to the skill of Willa Angel Chen Miller:

I was unfamiliar with a whopping 10 names in her puzzle, yet her crosses were so well done that it was not an impediment to solving.

I loved her conversational answers, like IT'S NOT A RACE, NO GREAT SHAKES, etc.

Made me work for this one, so pretty typical Friday.  Solved like a jigsaw puzzle, one piece at a time.  Time was 10% less than average.

Passed over "Ready to fight" several times before it dawned on me that ready was being used as a verb.  I bet Steve L. was not so easily fooled.

Who knew you could buy a town on EBay? (9A)
Tough one for me. Kind of a slog. Never heard the phrase NO GREAT SHAKES in my life

Anyways else think the caption of the picture is throwing some shade (*ahem* ... inconsistent) at the one-time USC quarterback?

"One way to guess whether Matt Leinart made a successful play is to flip a coin."

That just had to make me laugh.

Anyways, enjoyable puzzle.
Sea monster and one was a natick for me..otherwise a smooth solve.

I have never used Uber--do the drivers rate the customers, as well as vice versa? That's what the (grammatical) voice of the clue suggests. I can imagine the reviews--"Don't pick him up--he smelled bad, prattled incessantly the whole drive, and didn't tip!"

My first thought for 14D was the Borg Queen from Star Trek--talk about women in technology!

Beautifully balanced puzzle that
allowed common sense  (and some stabs in the dark)
to reveal names  I did *not* know!

From 4th to 9th grade, 
our youngest let his crewcut grow
into a *shocking*  fauxhawk.
With liberty spikes.

13” spikes that I had to spray glue gel 
and blow dry *every* morning.
For 4 years.

It was so unlike him.
He was the most shy, gentle boy.
He never called attention to himself in any other way.
Never, ever got in trouble.

His nickname in martial arts was 
The Gentle Warrior.
We said he was a turtle born without a shell.

But people would (obviously) stare,
point, ask to touch it, take *so* many photos…
I swear he just didn’t notice the spectacle.

Oddly, very few of the looks were negative.
If I did see a raised eyebrow, ready to judge,
I’d smile and rub his shoulder or put my arm
around him.
(He didn’t notice the leering, he was just a snuggler.)

I learned to see our local, adolescent
scruffy boys in such a different way!

When people asked (constantly)
how long we thought he’d keep it, I always said, 
“I think the it’ll be the day he doesn’t 
feel he’ll disappear without it.”

That day came, and he’s looked like
he’s on his way to an interview at a bank
ever since…

Happy Friday all!

A MONSTER debut.  Congratulations.  With late week puzzles I've come to expect that I'll be finishing up in the NW since that is often where the trickiest clues will lurk.  So the NE was my entry, worked clockwise and, yep, finished in the NW.  

Well done and many thanks.

“I’m giving those passengers a very poor three-star rating. They trashed the saucer after we visited the second star, and things just got worse from there.”

But a very fast puzzle!
The verbiage of 4D threw me off. Well done!

Ya gotta love a puzzle with a SEA MONSTER.

And a lesson in Chinese numbers. ONE, two, three . . 

Thanks, Willa!

A lovely candidate for a "themeless Wednesday" puzzle. Seemed awfully gentle for a Friday; solved it in half my Friday average. This was likely due to the many entries that were phrases, which I usually find easy to discern and that provide me with lots of letters. Quite a few proper nouns in the grid, but, atypically, these did not slow me down. 

"Shattering results" for SHARDS was clever.

What kept sparking joy for me, every time I turned a corner, it seemed, was wordplay in the cluing.  Wit that misdirected, wit that tickled.

Look at [Exchange letters] for IPO.  Its lovely double meaning misdirected me for a bit (and I find something very satisfying about being fooled through wordplay).  It’s an original clue for an answer that has appeared more than 400 times in the major crossword venues.  

Look at [Big whoop] for YELL, which triggered a smile.  Once again, here’s an answer that has shown up more than 200 times, sometimes clued as [Whoop], but never with the “big”, which, IMO, makes it infinitely better.

Look at the lovely misdirect [Hint] for NOTE, another never-before-used clue for an answer that has turned up more than 400 times in Crosslandia.   

And there were quite a bit more that Willa came up with.

Oh, I loved setting down the beautiful SHARDS, as well as the lovely PuzzPair© of ERAS and a backward AGES.

But what’s going to spark joy when I see your name atop another puzzle, Willa, is the thought of entering another word playground.  Thank you so much for making this!

Fun puzzle - loved the twists and turns . Just one quibble - don’t you give an Uber rating rather than get one ?? Had BOARDSPOTS and ROIL for the longest time before realizing what the saucer clue was about - DUH. Thanks for a fun solve !

I don't normally like conversational answers, but most of these just popped into my head fairly quickly. Two answers slowed me down a bit: a GRANDCHILD does not have to be a minor child. Mine just turned 18. And I thought for sure that once I got UBER so quickly it would be followed by SURVEY, since everyone wants you to do a survey nowadays, even though most don't get read. But overall a relaxing solve, so thanks Willa.
Great Friday. My last and favourite fill was the features of monks and punks (24D).

I puzzled and puzzled over Jörmungandr: world serpent, ouroboros, Loki's child? Once the haze lifted, it all opened like a flower, allowing a BRAVE (a great favorite among us fans of scaffy witches) march forward through the charmingly clever clues.

Thanks for the fun!
There was some truly great (and devious) clueing today. Bravo!

I seemed to be on the same page as the creator of this puzzle. I just started filling it in. With only a few minor corrections (changing a t to a p, for example), I found myself done. Seldom happens (for me), but nice when it does.

I usually love Friday puzzles, but not this one. As feedback these are two things I prefer to see less of in puzzles: first, there are 17 capitalized nouns. I prefer fewer. Second, the two “artful” language clues, at 37A and 27D weren’t fun. Figuring them out added little to my overall solving experience.

Good but very chewy; an awful lot of unknown names (paint brand, old Alaskan capital, as well as people) held me up for a while.
Was thrown by 1A; a SALAD is not a separate component of a meal here, simply one of a number of dishes in the starter course. Took me forever to work out we were talking food courses. 

Uber doesn’t operate outside of large cities here, so little idea of how they operate. I can barely find a simple taxi here in the sticks.

Was very pleased with myself for getting both 9A and 42D. Completing a daily US based crossword is definitely starting to have an effect.

All in all a very satisfying Friday; tough for me, but doable, with interesting fill. I particularly like the long entries at 6D, 25 and 40As. Plus who doesn’t love Wind in the Willows? Our battered family copy is in my eye-line as I fill in the puzzle.
Pretty tough one with all the names if you don't watch TV, go to kids' movies, or listen to rap. And for the life of me, I can't figure out "HPS" for printer purchases.

This was a good puzzle.  Lots of things I didn’t know: screenwriters, authors, movies, rap songs, mythological characters both Greek and Norse.  But without undue difficulty I was able to get those filled with the crossing clues.

In my youth my justification for doing crossword puzzles was that I often learned something.  I don’t feel the need to justify myself these days, but if I did today would be a case in point.

As people become more and more siloed in their own interests listening to their own subset of the multitudinous communication channels available these days, writing a crossword puzzle for a wide swath of the population must be more and more difficult.  This one did a good job of it.

Just off a PB - surprising after a slow start. After a few random entries, it came together from southeast to northwest - unusual for me. 
I didn't know some of the proper nouns, but was able to get them by the crosses. There were no Naticks that I can see. 
And I learned a few things. What more can you ask of a Friday?

This was an extremely fun puzzle. I loved NO GREAT SHAKES and IT'S NOT A RACE. Not one but two references to mythology had my little nerd brain dancing.

I got extremely stuck in the middle, though, with U-Haul instead of ALAMO.
One of my guitars has a SITKA spruce top, which helped me guess the Alaskan capital.
Gnome was not the first capital of Alaska. 🤦🏼‍♂️

Hmm.  I will check my bird books, but the EGRETs we see here are brilliant white--cattle egrets, giant egrets, snowy egrets.  All white.  
But that entry helped me change GReat niece to GRANDCHILD...
There were many Unknowns for me, but for some reason I was on the wave length for the longer phrases, and the crossings were essential....even if I never read _The Wind in the Willows._

24A  What is left of my coffee mug (after which disaster I signed up for carpal tunnel and cubital tunnel releases. ) Still looking for the "just right" replacement.  

Spelling the word ENOUGH always brings back a memory of a classroom scene when I was a HS special education teacher.....
Good stuff. Pretty darn speedy.
So clever!  And only two look-ups for me, which puts me in a good mood.

I enjoyed the puzzle, despite not knowing quite a few answers. They came easily with crosses and I learned quite a bit today. I confess, I will probably never get a handle on gods, goddesses, and their offspring. This community encouraged me to read Moby Dick several years ago, and I did, and am better for it (only because of the puzzle, not because I enjoyed the book), but mythology and I are polite to each other in company, and avoid each other in private.

I don't know anything about "Succession," but I do know some Shakespeare. Iago wasn't working, so it had to be King LEAR. Wasn't that the basis for "Sons of Anarchy?" That one I did watch.

Great Friday puzzle, with lots of clever cluing, but when's the last time we had an EAGLE on the reverse of the quarter? That would be 1998. I managed to collect all the states and territories, and most of the national parks, up to 2017, when I think I stopped using cash at the breakroom coffee machine.

Smooth and fast, with some fun cluing.  The top left gave me a bit of trouble but was solvable in the end.  Panic was short lived this time.  I did NOT much like the clue for IPO; it's a common entry and this particular clue seemed awkward to me.

Maybe a touch too easy for Friday, or maybe I'm finally getting smarter.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

This was fairly quick for me for a Friday, and I see I am not alone.

The clues were generally clever. I definitely struggled in a few places, but much of the puzzle fell in place as I moved along.

With all of the you-know-it-or-don't answers, it was interesting that I often knew them, whether because of true knowledge or by knowing that certain words get a lot of use here.

But as my times have gotten faster, I am no longer jealous of the people who report doing a hard puzzle in five or ten minutes. 

This one took about 22 minutes, and that was plenty fast. Any faster, and I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much.

Managed to get a few unknown proper nouns on crosses and guesses, but needed a couple of very grudging lookups to crack the areas around BEANE and OLGA, the latter of which should have been an easy guess from the two letters I already had.
Had completely the wrong end of the "Chinese horizontal line"---knowing the names of the various strokes in Mandarin was actively counterproductive.

But that was great fun, with some nice misdirection.

Wow.  This puzzle prompted a flashback.  Almost 60 years ago, I worked in the maps, microtext, and newspapers department in the basement of Olin Library at Cornell.  Part of my job was to put newspapers in chronological order for microfilming. Some of the papers were Chinese, so I needed to know Chinese numbers.  Who knew that the real purpose of that job was to prepare me for today's puzzle?  Alas, I got 5 Down only with the crosses.

Fun clues, fun answers.  Thank you!  

Alternate common name for Ardea ibis "cattle egret" is "buff backed egret" --learned a new thing.   

An Ardea alba "Great egret" landed in our garden last week, lost, staggering and exhausted from trying to fly in the horrific Santa Ana winds.  We left it to recover.  Hopefully it did.
Absolutely flew through this one and got the gold star in 8:19. Didn't really feel like Friday difficulty but a fun puzzle nonetheless.
Fun Friday! The monks and punks clue was super cute!

Whew! The devious clues in this crossword had me going in circles!

Somehow I managed to complete this tricky puzzle, and enjoyed myself doing it. It wasn't my fastest Friday time, but quite a bit faster than yesterday's puzzle.

There were so many clever clues I can't even pick the best one... but [Quarter back?] for EAGLE was a standout for me.
Who knew the Yiddish Policeman’s Union would provide valuable knowledge 17 years later?
It took me too long to put in GRANDCHILD. I thought of it early, but it didn't work with a (incorrect) crossing I had. When I finally filled it in just to check, everything else fell into place.
I'm not sure I've ever worked a puzzle with long words so easy to solve.

In other news, after scrolling through the comments, I'm much heartened to see that I finally got a gimme on a piece of American geography/history that gave some US posters pause. Alaska is the only US state I've travelled in extensively, and I've always been fascinated by its complicated history, along with Yukon next door. So there was a brief period when SITKA was the only solution I had on the grid!

Loved the conversational clues - they came easy for me, as they did for others, I see.

Just last night I was doing a Tuesday from 12/2/97 and 17A was SITKA!  Funny how stuff like that works out.

Good, fun Friday - thanks constructor!

I was as speedy as a MACO shark on 22D, a misspelling which led me to a variety of attempts at 25A that would end in ACES -- for a long time I struggled with the so-so NOTREALLYACES.  The SHAVEDHEADS finally straightened out my SLANTS.  Thanks for a great Friday work out!
Now I know that TOO is an adverb. But I'm still trying to wrap my mind around that.

Oh, that was fun. Took me longer than usual -- I don't watch Succession, so I had IAGO, but if I'd thought about the title for even a few seconds....

Great puzzle. Very satisfying.

This puzzle is a rare gem because I did not have to figure out who in 1955 baseball played on 3 different teams while breaking the RBI and home run records from the previous 10 years all while holding 4 different positions...! Yes, no sports clues, thank you Ms. Miller! Okay, the coin toss is sorta sports adjacent, and I thought it funny the photo heading the column was of a football player, but the clues were more of a kind you could SUSS out with crosses and/or some serious rumination. I know they'll be back, but today was just a breath of fresh air.

Very satisfying puzzle. I was on Ms. Miller’s wavelength I guess, as most of the phrases came pretty easily to mind. There were still challenges of course, but usually crosses helped in the areas that didn’t come quickly, such as the playwright I hadn’t heard of. I don’t watch Succession—tried some of the first season and it just wasn’t for me—but I do know my Shakespeare and it was pretty easy to see the connection to LEAR. Like Deb, the sale of the town of Buford was a surprise to me, but it had to be EBAY. 
Thanks to the whole team for a puzzle that put a smile on my face, especially in these scary and troubled times. We have family quite close to the horrendous fires down south, and so far they are all okay, but so many others have lost their homes, or worse. It’s pretty terrifying.
Excellent. Took me nearly an hour. Just one minor kvetch. The clue for Uber Rating was worded in a way to suggest Uber was rating you rather than the other way around

A slow start, but I really enjoyed this one. It all came together gradually, which is just what you want. 
After I got NOT A LITTLE and had the NO of 25A, I thought there might be a NOT theme, so confidently put a t to give me tRAN at 27D. That threw me for a while. 
I also guessed LEAR early (I've seen the show, but not the play) but erased it when I figured 13A must be staRRATING. Took a while to re-correct myself.
Being Australian, I didn't get Quarter back - even after I deduced it must be EAGLE, I didn't know why.  But I appreciated the lack of US sporting clues.
In all, a great and very satisfying puzzle, with no lookups!

Late puzzle find - don't recall another one like this one. Anyway... a Thursday from September 7, 2000 by Manny Nosowsky. You might have to look at this for a few seconds to get it. Theme clues and answers: Octet's peculiarity? : QUIRKOFEIGHT "Et tu, Brute?," e.g.? : QUESTIONOFACT What pollution in the Sargasso Sea may lead to? : LACKOFEELING And my favorite: One who babbles "baa, baa"? : MANOFEWEWORDS Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/7/2000&g=20&d=A ....
Wow, Elon Musk solved today's puzzle in 43 seconds, and I am not referring to the mini.

Sometimes a puzzle makes me rEGRET my lack of knowledge of some things. After reading the comments today, I realize that sometimes my lack of knowledge helps me... I had zero issues with plopping EGRET in at 29A because I have no idea what colors egrets are or how muscular they might be. I can't imagine they're very muscular but I blissfully went on my merry way never the wiser to their coloration. Though it does remind me of Brooklyn 99 when Capt Holt describes the coloring of a corn crake to a temporarily blind Kevin, as they walk through the woods. Hot pantones! https://youtube.com/watch?v=9i8L_bF2bv0 On the other end of my knowledge rests my wanting to enter queen at 14D... Well, Seven of Nine didn't fit, nor did Locutus (of Borg), so... ha! Obviously, it wasn't that but as they say, the heart wants what it wants. Lastly, so does anyone have an answer to the validity of 9A? I've read the previous comments about it, which sent me down a rabbit hole in which I found no satisfaction in my quest. I wondered if maybe the auction house had originally listed it on eBay, since I see they do online auctions now through an online auction site. Maybe the used eBay back then? Of course, this whole issue reminds me of another favorite comedy, Schitt's Creek, https://youtube.com/watch?v=78nwaHzgDks So, to sum up, a perfectly pleasant puzzle that reminded me of three of my favorite shows in the world.

I was a friend of Anita Borg, and I was so touched to see her name in the crossword (that Institute for Women in Technology is not named for her -- the Anita Borg Institute).  She was a great inspiration to many of us and I'm glad to see her remembered.  Thank you Willa Miller
I loved this puzzle!  My favorite clue pair was [Saucer contents, in brief]/ ETS and I loved swiftly keying in DIRECTDEPOSIT.
My first Friday 'Gold Star!' I am celebrating, even if it was on the easy side for the day!

Condolences to Deb on losing her dad. Her comments reminded me of my dad whom I watched do the Sunday puzzle ever since I can remember. When he collapsed and died in January of 1987 the half-finished Sunday puzzles slipped from his hands to the floor. I don't remember which week but I do remember that 1 across clue was (Four New Testament books.) Wish I could find it somewhere online.

This is an awesome crossword puzzle. Crunch is good... the crunchier the better... this is a great example of why we don't need gimmicks in these puzzles... it can be challenging and fun while staying remaining faithful to the fundamentals of the game.
If you're so sure flying saucers are full of ETs why aren't there more ET hotels? This planet is SO inhospitable.

Oooft. Too tough for me today, but that’s not me saying this puzzle was the PITS - I’m just NO GREAT SHAKER yet !! Enjoyed the bits I did manage, and after all, ITS NOT A RACE - the only people to compete with are the various versions of me. GOOD ENOUGH for this ONE.
ENCORE was my last fill-in, which was very appropriate for a very fun and nicely challenging puzzle. More from Ms. Miller, please! ENCORE, indeed!
NOGREATSHAMES had a chokehold on me for ages until I realised it was NOGREATSHAKES. Not sure I've heard that term before. Otherwise, a cracking Friday crossword. A very enjoyable solve.
Kept thinking of "seven-of-nine" for Borg who co-founded the Institute for Women in Technology.  Turns out this clue was set in reality!
way too many obscure proper nouns. really not fun when you have to look up so many names. again... this isn't trivia...
Marvelous. Not too many proper nouns, and they were accessible from the crunchy crosses. Fun!

My second day with no word check but a correction on one letter from the constructor.
+I had UBER Review before UBER RATING. I was afraid of this one but just kept going and really enjoyed it.
had very little after my first pass but i guess i vibed w this one after all! well below my avg time :D
Buford Wyoming was not sold on eBay.

I enjoyed this puzzle!  

My one minor gripe was the clue for 6 Across, “Exchange letters.”  That is a bit of stretch for  “IPO” as the answer.  I used to work on IPOs in a former life.  To me a better answer to that clue would be “NASD” or “NYSE.”  It’s a few degrees of separation to get to “IPO” from that clue.  

Otherwise, I thoroughly enjoyed this.  And as someone who can’t always complete a Friday, I was super proud of myself!
What happened to fact checking? Numerous news articles from the time indicate an in-person auction for Buford WY operated by an Oklahoma auction house…

@Marshall Walthew and @Mason

@Marshall Walthew 

Now, by "buff" do you mean a color or ripped?

@Mason I think it's exceedingly unlikely that they meant buff as in muscular. If anything, that would be an even more odd choice seeing that we don't usually think of birds as particularly muscular creatures in general and egrets are especially thin and lithe in the bird world.
@Marshall Walthew I was puzzled by EGRET too - never seen one that wasn't white.

@Marshall Walthew I was surprised by buff as a descriptor for an egret as well. A post-solve search led me to this: https://sibleyguides.com/2012/05/an-unusual-cattle-egret-in-florida/ Apparently, cattle egrets have varying degrees of buff coloration. Who knew?

Nancy J.,

Thanks for the post. I, too, had never heard of non-white egrets. Seems (from that post alone) like quite a niche clue?

@Marshall Walthew I, too, love the Wind in the Willows and almost wore out my childhood copy from all the many re-readings. @Nancy J. Interesting.  Thank you for sharing.  What a great picture!

@Marshall Walthew 
Cattle regrets are mostly white, but have varying degrees of buff color depending on the season. The color comes from oil they secrete, so older feathers in certain areas will be more buff, freshly molted feathers will be white.

@Marshall Walthew Google suggests that "buff egret" or "buff-backed heron" are alternative names for the cattle egret (even though it too is partly white), so I guess that's in bounds.  I also guessed Shrek first!
@Sal Z I too was mystified by this clue, and after the solve went to google to learn what a buff marsh was. Easy enough to get from crosses, but an odd clue nonetheless.

Strands #320
“The time of our lives”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🟡
@Jane Wheelaghan ETS is short for Extraterrestrials. And yes, SALAD is often a first course in the US.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
Often, but not necessarily first--an appetizer or soup course may precede it. But is an introduction to the entree course. (Which isn't what "entrée" means in French--I know.)

At our hotel, it has become common for the salads to be preset: i. e. they are already on the tables when the guests enter the room. Also, sometimes desserts--the stated reason being that, if it's a meeting with a "keynote speaker," the client doesn't want the distraction of plates being cleared and relaid during the speech. But I put it down to the laziness of our servers, who would rather be in the wings, watching soccer. I always object--who wants to eat soggy, room-temperature cheesecake? Or do the guests eat it the moment they sit down? Plus it means I get a half-hour less to get the task done, and have to prepare the maximum number of servings--200 say, when I know perfectly well only 180 people are likely to show up. Ah well, at the end of the night, more room-temperature cheesecake for the soccer-fans.

(A window onto my world)
@Jane Wheelaghan A single horizontal line is the character for “one”

@Jane Wheelaghan Yes, Miss Manners explains that restaurants in the US began serving salad  before the main course because it can be prepared in advance and taken to the table quickly. And because Americans assume that anything done in restaurants is correct, it has become the norm. As the comments make clear, almost no one knows that salad was traditionally served AFTER the main.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
My query too Jane;  not the norm for us either, or the UK in general, but some enlightening answers here to your query.

@Bill 

Being in the business, you've undoubtedly seen more events than I have, but in my limited experience of maybe a half-dozen events a year, the norm I've encountered is what I mentioned above.  Of course, most of these events are not top-tier catering; they're very much for middle class weddings and professional events like conventions and retirement parties.  Certainly fancier events would have more elaborate structures.

When I was in France back in the last century, I was taken to a restaurant where dinner service lasted about four hours.  By the time it was over, it was way past my bedtime.  That affair had all the courses, the intermezzi, the amuse-bouches, the salad, the soup, etc.  It cost us the princely sum of about $100...which was a kings' ransom for a teacher in 1985.  But what a meal!

(Miss Manners also thinks, take the utensils from the outside...)

@Steve L 
"ocassionally," being the operative adverb, in my post. Not the norm.

@Steve L 
Thank you all for your responses. Quite a history lesson re salads!
I lived in NYC from 1974-75. My boyfriend's father was Chinese and we always ate Chinese (Chun Cha Fu on Broadway at 91st) and nary a lettuce leaf passed our lips. 
Now I often have a salad as a main course, or I have a side salad with my main course, but never first. Almost as odd as having a doughnut for breakfast ....

@MB 
Thanks. I was confused by Deb's comment that she 'guessed' and I thought I was missing something.

@Bill 
Thanks for this. I've never seen dessert already on the table as you come in!

@Suzanne 

My grandfather, my father-in-law and a few other older Italian Americans that I have known ate their salads at the end of the meal. Usually with just a little red wine vinegar and olive oil. (My Papa would pile his plate high and claim it made him feel “less full.” 🤷‍♂️)

@Jane Wheelaghan 
I'm surprised that almost all the comments say that in the US, the salad precedes the main course.  I've always eaten the salad after the main, both growing up and in my adult home.

Peter,

It’s a phrase that mostly reminds me of my mother, who said it often. Another one she used was “I’ll be there in two shakes of a dead lamb’s tail” which seemed to imply she was busy, but would try to get there as soon as she could, but don’t hold your breath.
@JohnWM My mother said "two shakes of a lambs' tail" (not dead) to indicate "quick."

@Peter 
I've heard NO GREAT SHAKES occasionally. It's definitely a thing.

@Katie 

"In two shakes of a little lamb's tail," was a cutesy phrase addressed to children when I was a kid, meaning, "quick" or "soon".

@Peter 
I've heard the expression and know what it means, but not why. My guess is that something is ground-breaking it "shakes things up."

@Grant 

A number of these "shake" metaphors are traced back to shaking (and then rolling) dice. "A fair shake" (a fair deal), "a couple of shakes" (a short time, without the involvement of lambs), and "no great shakes" (nothing impressive, in the sense of a so-so outcome from a roll of the dice).

@chris 
A "natick" occurs when the crossing letter of two entries can't be deduced from the cross (two proper nouns, usually): although they cross, once you have SEA MONST_R and ON_, what other letter than "E" could it be?

@Bill I remembered Kenneth G. spellt his name funny, but couldn't remember how--where, exactly, did that "H" go? But a little personal history--

My Partner--whom I often refer to in these comments--was not read to as a child. No sense of the "classics"--Pooh, the Wind in the Willows, the Little Prince. I have tried to rectify this, but with little success.

When I was first getting to know him, we spent a weekend at the cabin in Northern (Lower) Michigan, which he bought with his Ex, and which sits in a small, inland lake. One afternoon, first we took out the pontoon boat, then we took out the paddle boat, then the tandem kayak. "I just being on the water!" he said.

" 'Just messing about in boats!'--Oh my god, you ARE the Water Rat, from the Wind in the Willows--you even look like him!" (He has sandy blond hair.)

"I'm not rat!" he countered.

"No, you don't understand--the Water Rat is a very _good_ character. But I guess that would make me the Mole--I'm not sure I like that comparison."

@Bill 
Exactly how it works

@Bill 
"on the lake," not "in"--duh!
@Bill Yes, drivers rate passengers as well. As with passengers' ratings of drivers, most are just ratings with no reviews. If you use a rideshare, you can see your rating in the app.

@Bill 
We have a framed copy of the Water Rat's "simply messing about in boats" quote hanging up at our lake camp. Because that's what we do.

@Bill 
My proofreading is particularly bad this morning: "just love being," "a rat," etc.

@CCNY I also learned to view teenaged boys through a different lens via my son and his parade of friends who made themselves comfortable at my house. Some scruffy, some spiffy, some speaking in "weird" (to me) jargon. They were polite and helped me lug in the groceries they also helped me eat. My door was always open to them, literally. Good times. Can't believe it was about 20 years ago.

@CCNY 
I sported a Mohawk in the summer before I went into the Army, because they were going to shave it all off anyway. If I'd done that while still in HS, I would have been sent home immediately.

@Xword Junkie 

Yes!  I second the motion for the themeless Wednesday idea.

@Mean Old Lady 
All cattle egrets have some degree of buff coloring, except when they have just molted. The color comes from the oil they secrete to coat their feathers, so older feathers are more buff (usually moreso on head and chest) while new feathers are pure white.
